Butts; by inheritance in 1905 to his widow; sold April 1906 through Carfax & Co. to W. Graham Robertson; sold from Robertson's collection, Christie's, 22 July 1949, lot 10 (£462 to Ian L. Phillips); by bequest to the Tate Gallery (now Tate Collection) in 1984, with a life interest to Phillips' widow, who relinquished the interest in 1986.

desc.objtitle: Moses Indignant at the Golden Calf, Object 1 (Butlin 387)

objnote.p: Blake signed the work with his monogram lower left; see the textual transcription. An enhanced image of the monogram has been provided below.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design illustrates Moses's return from the top of Mount Sinai and his discovery of the idolatry and profligacy around the golden calf (Exodus 32:16). The figure of Moses dominates the design. He has a beard and wears a transparent gown. He faces forward, but looks to the left with his mouth open. His arms are raised above his head, with one palm facing forward and one palm up. His left foot is extended forward. His expression suggests surprise and anger. At Moses's feet lie the cracked stone tablets bearing the ten commandments. To Moses's left are three nude figures. One figure, seen from behind, has its arms raised at 135 degrees and stands on tiptoe, with left leg behind the right. The figure's posture is dance-like. The figure holds a sistrum (an ancient Egyptian musical instrument) in the right hand and a tambourine in the left. The figure also faces right and appears to be kissing a figure who faces forward with head turned to the left. Both figures have short, curly hair; their gender is unclear. Behind these two appears to be a figure of indeterminate gender with its arms raised, facing away and looking right. The idol of the golden calf stands on a stone(?) plinth or altar to the left of Moses and above the smaller cavorting figures. It faces right. Though the background is dark, there are indications of mountains or hills right of Moses. Dark smoke billows across the sky behind Moses. The smoke is red at its edges, suggesting the fires of burnt offerings. The sky upper left includes a few reddish clouds, either reflecting the implied fire or a sunrise or sunset. There may be grass on the ground lower left.

component.illusobjdesc: The figure of Moses dominates the design. Moses has a beard and wears a transparent gown. He stands, legs spread, and faces forward, but looks to the left with his mouth open. His arms are raised above his head, with the right palm facing forward, fingers slightly spread. The left palm faces up and out. His left foot is extended forward and his large knees are prominent. His expression suggests surprise and anger.

At Moses's feet lie the cracked and broken stone tablets bearing the ten commandments. The tablet below his left foot, just left of the right margin of the design, is only a fragment. The tablet on the left may contain slight suggestions of Hebrew letters.

To Moses's left are three nude figures. One figure, seen from behind, has its arms raised at 135 degrees and stands on tiptoe, with left leg behind the right. The posture is dance-like (see the reference to "dancing" in Exodus 32:19). The figure holds a sistrum (an ancient Egyptian musical instrument) in the right hand and a tambourine in the left. The figure also faces right and appears to be kissing a figure who faces forward with head turned to the left. Both figures have short, curly hair; their gender is uncertain.

To Moses's left are three nude figures. Behind the two kissing figures appears to be a figure of indeterminate gender with its arms raised, facing away and looking right. The raised left hand may be grasping the upper edge of the plinth or altar below the golden calf. Butlin 387 identifies this figure as Aaron. The painting is considerably decayed in the area of this figure's head.
The idol of the horned golden calf stands on a stone(?) altar or plinth to the left of Moses and above the smaller cavorting figures. It faces right.
Though the background is dark, there are indications of mountains or hills in the distance right of Moses.
There may be grass on the ground, lower left.

Dark smoke billows across the sky behind Moses. The smoke is red at its edges, suggesting the fires of burnt offerings. The sky upper left includes a few reddish clouds, either reflecting the implied fire or a sunrise or sunset.
